Investigation 3

Using Exponents to Express the Multiplicative Structure of Numbers

Finding ways to express numbers as products of whole- number factors is helpful. In this investigation, we will use exponents as an efficient way to express products that involve the same factor more than once. For example, we can write 100 as different factor pairs.

1 × 100

2 × 50

4 × 25

5 × 20

10 × 10

Also, we can write 100 as the product of three factors. Strings of factors for a number are called factorizations.

2 × 2 × 25

2 × 5 ×10

The number 100 can be written as a product of four factors: 2 × 2 × 5 × 5. We can use shorthand notation to write factorizations. For example, with

The small, raised number is an exponent. An exponent tells us how many times a factor is used. The expression 22 × 52 contains whole-number exponents.

A factorization of 10 is 10 = 21 × 51.

Note if the exponent is 1, we write the number without the exponent. So 10 = 2 × 5.

We can read some exponents in more than one way.
